titleStmt.title: John F. Galbraith et al. to James F. Robinson
CWG8737

availability.p: This image and transcription is publicly accessible. The image appears courtesy of the repository named in the Source Description. The transcription and annotation were undertaken by Kentucky Historical Society staff, volunteers, and interns. If referencing this document title, accession number, and permanent URL.

seriesStmt.title: Civil War Governors of Kentucky Digital Documentary Edition

msIdentifier.repository: Kentucky Department for Libraries and Archives
msIdentifier.collection: Office of the Governor, James F. Robinson: Governor's Official Correspondence File, Petitions for Pardons, Remissions, and Respites, 1862-1863

body.p:
To his Excelency Jas. F. Robinson
Gov. of the Commonwealth of Ky.

The undersigned citizens of Webster County, Ky, would state & most respectfully represent unto your Excelency that the Webster Circuit at its present March Term, co-mencing on the 9th day of March 1863 entered a Judgement against one Micager Cobb for penal sum of $2000 upon a charge of Selling liquor by retail without a licen therefor

They would state that said "liquor' was retailed at a sale that said Cobb before selling siad Liquor as charged asked & obtained the permission of N, N, Johnson the owner of the adjacent premises. That said Johnson granted to said Cobb the privildge of selling upon his land & told him that he would not be violating the Law in so doing & that said Cobb having further consulted one a Justice of the peace in & for Webster county & being instructed by him in substance that if he (Cobb) had obtained the permission of Johnson to sell Liquor by retail on his Johnsons land ^that^ the he would not Violate the Law in so doing

They state that said Cobb has ever been a peaceful orderly & quiet citizens -- that he is a very poor man -- That he has a large & helpless family ^entirely^ dependent upon him for support & that they verily believe that said Cobb acted in the foregoing premise in honest faith believing that he was violating no Law & committing no wrong

Wherefore your petitioners would most
respectfully ask that said fine be remitted

Fondly hoping that your Excelency upon a due due consideration of the premises will take such action as is herein asked (in remitting said fine &c) yours petitioners will ever pray &c
Dixon Ky. March 1863

J. E. Price
John Brown
A W Mooney
g w Morgan
Dan Christian
Thomas W Colby
Dabney N Trice
